body: Can you explain more about what you want to do? Passing additional data to a formatter isn’t going to change what ESLint is outputting, as that message doesn’t come from a formatter.

> Can you explain more about what you want to do? Passing additional data to a formatter isn’t going to change what ESLint is outputting, as that message doesn’t come from a formatter.

Yes, but it will enable formatter to display an additional message in case it's needed. It will let formatter know about the situation. 
In case of warnings being exceeded it only logs a static message and throws: 
`Error: Npm failed with return code: x`
In my use case (azure pipeline CI/CD) static log message cannot be reformatted to `vsts` format and I end up with a message that indicates error but doesn't give any information about the cause.

With additional information using the formatter I could just push one more message to the output warnings/errors stack in `vsts` error format explaining what happened (and letting default azure pipelines UI do display it).

Also, I see no downsides in having more information in formatter function.

If ESLint is already outputting a warning about this, why would a formatter also output a warning? That’s what I don’t understand. This doesn’t seem like a good user experience.

> Also, I see no downsides in having more information in formatter function.

All functionality has a maintenance cost and user expectation cost.

> If ESLint is already outputting a warning about this, why would a formatter also output a warning? That’s what I don’t understand. This doesn’t seem like a good user experience.

It doesn't have to, in my use case, it would, because there is no other way to format it to `vsts` format (that I can think of). The point is just to pass information to formatter function, for formatter authors to do with it what they want.

> > Also, I see no downsides in having more information in formatter function.
> 
> All functionality has a maintenance cost and user expectation cost.

That's a good point. Maybe I'm taking a bad approach because I'm too inspired by `stylelint`'s resolution to the problem.
Do you have any thoughts about my use case?

> Do you have any thoughts about my use case?

I still don’t understand what your use case is. You’ve expressed that you want the data in a formatter, but not why this makes sense to ESLint. 

We can’t leave it up to formatters to output this information because people will forget, that’s why ESLint outputs it directly. Otherwise every formatter will need to remember to implement it and that means the warning could go unnoticed.

So again, given that the core is already outputting this warning, and it’s not really safe to remove it, what is the value of passing this info to formatters?

I think that formatter is supposed to format output.
Even without removing or modifying original functionality, I think it's worth it for formmater to know about the full output. As far as I understand custom formatter doesn't have to implement (or mirror) all messages that original/default does. 
This means that having this information will allow the formatter to interact with it, for example drawing a random circle like in a school notebook or, in my case, creating an additional message for the CI/CD environment.

Again, I’m just looking for a use case that might be applicable to more than just you. 

> creating an additional message for the CI/CD environment.

you mean in addition to the default message? What would that message look like? How would that message be more valuable than the default? Or do you mean that you are making some kind of a API call that registers somewhere else inside your CI system? Please be as specific as possible.

Unfortunately, there is only one use case I can think of and it's having the ability to create additional messages in case of the condition being exceeded. It can be more valuable because it would be in format that the current env can read (e.g.  `##vso[task.logissue type=error] ESLint found too many warnings (maximum: %s)`). There is no need to do any additional API calls or anything.
But it's agnostic of my environment. 
The authors of other formatters maybe would like to print additional messages in their style too.
- Jenkins users in jenkins-parsable format.
- VS code users in a format that their editor can read
etc.
@eslint/eslint-tsc I could use some help here. Is this something we want to pursue?

To summarize my understanding, the problem is that ESLint is printing information to `stderr` that isn't available to formatters. The motivating use case is a CI pipeline that surfaces ESLint messages read from a machine-readable formatter. Currently, the CI tool shows a build failed and can't explain why it failed despite having only warnings. Do I understand that correctly?

If so, I agree that's not a great experience. I'd think in principle that any information that determines the exit status of a normal (i.e. non-crashing) lint run should be available to the formatter.

Yes, you understand correctly. Where I’m having trouble is with the expected behavior. If ESLint is already outputting a warning that cannot be removed, the only purpose of delivering that data to a formatter is to output the same thing again. That seems unexpected to me. Or maybe it means we shouldn’t output a message by default and we should leave it up to formatters to output. This is what I need help resolving in my brain.

> This is what I need help resolving in my brain.

Got it, thanks for clarifying.

> maybe it means we shouldn’t output a message by default and we should leave it up to formatters to output.

I'm leaning this direction. Whenever ESLint is run in a CLI, `stderr` is a perfectly standard place to put diagnostic messages like this one, and you're right that the formatter re-outputting it would be redundant. Unfortunately that makes the message inaccessible to non-CLI interfaces. Moving messages like this to the formatter puts CI tools and editor integrations back on a level playing field.

> Moving messages like this to the formatter puts CI tools and editor integrations back on a level playing field.

Right, but what about the transition? If we remove the default message we are outputting, not all formatters will know to output a message for max warning count, which means people could miss it. That’s my big concern.

If we decide this is worth changing, we could do feature detection on the formatter somehow, perhaps by making this new property on the data we pass to the formatter a getter that records when it’s been read. If the formatter doesn’t read it, then we could still print the message.

Or we could tell formatters we’re going to start passing it immediately, but we’ll keep printing up until 9.0.0. If they care about a redundant message, they can do feature detection on ESLint.

**TSC Summary:** This issue proposes passing the maximum warning limit into formatters. Right now, we output max warning problems directly to `stderr`, which means formatters don't have access to this information. 

**TSC Questions:**

1. Do we want to pass information about maximum warnings into formatters?
2. Do we want to change how ESLint outputs this warning (stop outputting, change to a linter error, or other)?

We decided in the TSC meeting that we'd like to make the maximum warning threshold available to formatters. We don't want to change ESLint's existing output for this case so that existing CLI formatters don't need to change anything, but non-CLI formatters like the one used in this issue thread will have the information they need to display an appropriate message.

We still need to decide on this issue exactly how ESLint should pass the maximum warning threshold to formatters.
@eslint/eslint-tsc does anyone on the TSC want to champion this change? If not, it’s time to close this issue.
